datafield.subfield: Linda Arvidson, Gertrude Robinson, Robert Drouet, Charles Perley, Jack Brammall, William J. Butler, Charles West.
Cast from Niver's Early motion pictures, p. 29. Probable production and distribution companies from Wikipedia article, Klaw & Erlanger.

Beverly Calhoun is invited by her friend, Princess Yestive of Graustark, to pay her a visit. On her journey, she is waylaid by bandits, and becomes entangled in the political problems of a neighboring country, whose ruler Prince Dantan, has been ousted by his evil half-brother Gabriel. Dantan, disguised as a simple goat hunter, has been driven into hiding in the mountains with his followers. Beverly is rescued by his band of rebels, but is mistaken for Princess Yestive. Beverly and Dantan fall in love, but their romance is complicated, not only by the hostilities between the two countries, but also because neither of them knows the true identity of the other.
Summary derived from copyright description (synopsis and continuity).
Based on the novel by George Barr McCutcheon.
Paper print shelf number (LC 2285) was changed when the paper prints were re-housed.

After being refused a loan by his cousin, Galora, an angry Antonine vows revenge. When Galora's wife leaves their apartment for a few minutes, her baby is home alone. Antonine sees his chance. He ties the child to a rope suspended precariously over a five-story drop. Then he follows Galora and tries to stab him. When caught by the police, Antonine boasts about the child in danger, giving the father enough time to rush home and affect a rescue.
Parts of summary from the Internet movie database and the Biograph bulletins, 1908-1912.

A greedy tycoon decides, on a whim, to corner the world market in wheat. This doubles the price of bread, forcing the grain's producers into charity lines and further into poverty. Shows the differences between the lives of those who work to grow the wheat and the life of the man who dabbles in its sale for profit.
Summary from the Internet movie database.
Based on the novel, The pit, by Frank Norris.

"A rural schoolmaster, beloved by his pupils, is dismissed from his teaching post when the county's visiting school inspector is mildly ridiculed in a cartoon that a mischievous pupil has drawn on the blackboard. When the schoolmaster replacement attempts to teach a class, he is driven from the school by the angry pupils. The pupils then go to the school commissioners and successfully insist on the reinstatement of their teacher"--The Griffith project, v. 4, p. 185.

An attractive young lady at a beach resort draws unwanted attention from a group of unruly young men, so she disguises herself with a long beach coat and plenty of padding. Not recognizing the beauty they had seen earlier, the young men jeer and tease her, all except for a plain-looking sailor, who likes her despite her large size. In the final scene, she is restored to her normal size, promenading on the arm of the young sailor.
Part of summary from the Early motion pictures catalog.
Originally released as part of a split reel with What's your hurry?, which LC also holds in the Paper Print Collection.

Photographed on July 29, August 3, and August 5-6, 1909 in Cuddebackville, New York, and in the Biograph studio in New York City.

At the outbreak of the Civil War, a Kentucky family is divided when the elder son, Robert, chooses to fight with the South, while the younger son, George, chooses to fight with the North. Their parents are equally divided: Mr. Wilkenson is a Union sympathizer, while Mrs. Wilkenson is for the Confederates. A few years into the war, both boys are fighting in Kentucky, near their home. Robert, now an officer, is charged with carrying sealed orders though Union lines. He is spotted by a Northern platoon, led by George. Robert is captured and the boys recognized each other. Robert escapes, and is pursued by his captors. Over his father's objections, he takes refuge in the family home, hidden under a bed by his mother. When George arrives to search the room, his mother draws a gun and threatens to kill herself if George takes his brother. Reluctantly, George tells his men the room is empty, and they leave without their prisoner. When the war is over, George returns home a hero, while poor bedraggled Robert watches the celebration from outside the house. He turns to leave, but is stopped by a servant, and brought inside. George asks him to pledge allegiance to the Stars and Stripes, but he won't. Carrying his ragged Confedrate flag, Robert turns again to leave, but George relents and the family is reconciled at last.
Part of summary from The Griffith project, v. 3.

According to the AFI catalog online, this film was originally tinted and toned, and was complete in 972 feet (35 mm).

William bids farewell to his blind fiancee, Molly. He meets the sophisticated Cora at a party and becomes so infatuated with her that he forgets Molly. Joseph, Molly's brother, writes to William to ask why they haven't received any letters. Cora finds the note and decides to visit Molly. When she realizes that Molly is indeed blind, Cora commits suicide so that William can marry Molly, as he promised to do.
Most of summary from the AFI STAR database. Parts of summary from Variety, October 15, 1910.
Film identified by Madeline Matz, M/B/RS reference librarian.

Sources used: AFI catalog online, viewed March 30, 2017; AFI STAR database, record number 4644 (Unidentifed AFI Miscellaneous No. 2. Reliance drama); Variety, October 15, 191; Internet movie database, March 30, 2017; M/B/RS Film & Television catalog card.

Grace, a disfigured young woman with two beautiful sisters, Vivian and Daisy, falls in love with Carl Wagner, a blind violinist, and they become engaged. Though she fears losing his love when he sees the scar on her face, Daisy pays for the surgery that restores Carl's sight. After his vision is restored, Vivian and Daisy both vie for Carl's attention, but to no avail. He still loves Grace.
Summary derived from synopses in Early motion pictures, and in Moving picture world.
According to The Griffith project, v. 3, p. 91, although the Biograph bulletin identifies the heroine as Grace, a letter insert identifies the character as Martha.

Emily turns down an offer of marriage from sailor Joe, and accepts sailor Bill. He sails away and soon forgets about his promise to Emily, leaving her to wait for six, long years. Unbeknownst to her, he marries and has a child. She waits, despite entreaties from Joe and the ridicule of her neighbors. Eventually she becomes deathly ill. When Bill returns with his wife and child, Joe forces him to make Emily's final moments happy, pretending he has returned to marry her.
Part of summary from the Griffith project, v. 3.

Letty sees her boyfriend Clarence with his head close to her cousin's as they are engrossed in a book and this causes her to flirt with her Clarence's friend, Felix, who takes Letty for a rowboat ride on the grand canal of Venice, California, and somehow falls in the water. During the period he is under the water, Clarence rescues Letty with another rowboat, which causes a great deal of consternation when poor, abandoned Felix surfaces and finds Letty missing.
Parts of summary from Early motion pictures and the Biograph bulletins.

After being jilted by their respective sweethearts, Dick Harcourt and Dora Dean have both become disenchanted with the opposite sex. Unknown to each other, they happen to share a seat on a passenger train. Due to a misunderstanding, the other passengers mistake them for newlyweds. As it happens, Dick is a member of an anti-marriage society, the members of which prepare a protest to his defection. Meanwhile, Dick and Dora are the recipients of so many wedding presents that they decide to get married after all.
Parts of summary from The Griffith project, v. 4 and the Biograph bulletins, 1908-1912.

Mary Pickford, William A. Quirk, James Kirkwood, Kate Bruce, Mack Sennett, Arthur Johnson, Owen Moore, W.J. Butler, Robert Harron, Harry Solter, Anthony O'Sullivan, Gladys Egan, John R. Cumpson, Henry B. Walthall, Gertrude Robinson.

Bessie's father discovers his daughter and Harry in the middle of a passionate declaration of love, and admonishes them--they are too young for marriage! Bessie and Harry are offended. To prove he is wrong, they decide to elope. Leaving a note, they start out in a buggy that breaks down, so they continue on foot. They hitch a ride in an automobile that blows up. Positive that their pursuers must be close behind, they start running (though in fact, no one is chasing them!) Bessie collapses from exhaustion, so Harry borrows a wheelborrow from a passing farmer. They continue until they come to a boat landing, get in a canoe, start paddling, and somehow manage to fall out. In sheer disgust, the bedraggled couple return home, unmarried. There they find that Bessie's mother and father have not been chasing them at all, but instead have invited all their friends to a wedding feast, and even have the minister there, just in case. The muddy, sodden pair are married at last!
Parts of summary from Early motion pictures, p. 325, and from the Biograph bulletins, 1908-1912, p. 114.

Happily married, Mr. and Mrs. Normand are soon blessed with a child. Unfortunately, as the baby grows up, the Normands become less interested in the child, and more interested in their social lives. By the age of eight, their child is being cared for mostly by the governess. Alone and neglected, the child becomes seriously ill. Alarmed and remorseful, Mr. Normand begs his wife to stay at home with him and care for their child. Mrs. Normand, who does not believe the child is very sick, leaves home to attend a party. While she is gone, the child's condition worsens. Mrs Normand rushes home, but she is too late. Her only child is dead. Mr. Normand blames his wife for the tragedy and leaves her. At her child's graveside, Mrs. Normand grieves and prays for forgiveness. Mr. Normand, also drawn to the grave, overhears and the two are reconciled.
Parts of summary from The Griffith project, v. 3 and Early motion pictures.
Incomplete: 35 mm. material in the AFI/Tayler Collection is about 5 minutes shorter than Paper Print material. Most of the beginning half of the film is missing, and end title is lacking.

Henry and Marion have a lover's quarrel and part in anger. They do not reconcile, and ten years pass without contact. Marion becomes a society girl and spends her time at parties with her friends. Henry has become very ill and wishes to see Marion one more time. He writes asking her to visit. When she recieves the note, she laughs and tosses it on the floor, but, later, on a whim, decides to take all her drunken friends with her to visit him. When they arrive, Marion finds Henry dead, clutching her portrait in his hand. She sends her friends away and falls to her knees in remorse.
Parts of summary from The Griffith project, v. 2.

Photographed May 13 and May 24, 1909 in in Edgewater, New Jersey and in the Biograph studio in New York City.

Tom Herne geoes out West with the intention of earning enough money to marry Mabel Jarrett. While he is away, Mabel has an accident while lighting a lamp and is terribly burned. The burns heal, but her face is scarred for life. Her cousin Winnie and the rest of her family try to console her, assuring her that Tom will still love her despite the scars. When Tom does return, he is visibly shocked by Mabel's appearance, but tries persuade her that it doesn't matter to him. Mabel soon realizes that it does matter to him. She also sees that Tom and Winnie have become close. To spare Mabel any more pain, Winnie decides to leave, but Mabel discovers her plans. Leaving a farewell note in which she releases Tom to marry Winnie, Mabel fakes her own death and devotes the rest of her life to caring for the children at the Orphan Asylum.
Parts of summary from The Griffith project, v. 2.

At a birthday party, the father of the house is given a double-barrel shotgun, over which he is most enthusiastic. Meanwhile, his daughter recieves a letter saying that her boyfriend will be home from college early. When the boyfriend arrives and see the shotgun, he misunderstands and departs in terror. He runs into people, knocks them down, breaks things, and finally is brought back into the young lady's arms by the father he had feared was going to shoot him.
Parts of summary from the Early motion pictures catalog and the Internet movie database.

Archive for floral fairies and rainbow fairies.

Consists of mock-up of book "Floral fairies: Adventures of Johnny Jump-up" and extra suite of 15 water color renderings by Alberta Hall for the book. Includes 2 color design drawings of Rainbow Fairies, small packet of 6 wax crayon color drawings and 5 drafts of unpublished typescript "Rainbow Fairies," 2 drafts of "Rainbow fairies, half-tone colors" and "Semi-tone color, Rainbow fairies, part II" and "Scientific relation of tone, color and thought and their symbols and forms" and sketchbook with text "Vibration and color" by Gertrude Ina Robinson. Also includes samples of commercial licensing material for 38 gift tags, sticker labels and mock-ups with designs by Gertrude Ina Robinson and copy of Dennison's Christmas book 1913 including advertising for those designs and photograph of catalog page with those designs. Includes business card for Gertrude Ina Robinson, harpist accompanying gift card samples with typewritten note on verso: "Copyright Sept. 21st, 1907 by Gertrude Ina Robinson. All rights reserved". Also includes portrait of unidentified man in U.S. military chaplain's uniform in an Underwood & Underwood, N.Y. portfolio used as stiff backing for Rainbow fairies drawings.

Box 1: Typescripts. Crayon drawings (11 items) -- Box 2: Mock up book of Floral fairies. Adventures of Johnny Jump-Up by Gertrude Ina Robinson, pictures by Alberta Hall -- 15 original watercolors by Alberta Hall for illustrations in Johnny Jump-Up -- Packet of gift tags including mockups and labels and Dennison's Christmas book 1913 catalog (43 items) -- Two drawings for Rainbow fairies -- Portrait of unidentifed man in military chaplain uniform.
